abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is overall satisfactory.
            The sustainability of the PAVCOPA project will probably vary
            depending on the category of beneficiary. The increasing
            professionalism of producers, processors and traders and
            their involvement in the associative movement will probably
            have lasting effects, since it has increased their revenues
            and helped them to become operational within Mali's
            administrative and legal environment. The sustainability of
            the vitality that the project injected into the Chambers of
            Agriculture cannot yet be assessed. The Bank's overall
            performance is rated marginally satisfactory. The Bank
            recognized implementation errors by the executing agency and
            took responsibility for addressing the shortcomings. As a
            result, the project staff was replaced in 2001 and a new
            implementation plan prepared and launched at a workshop in
            Selingue. That workshop produced, within a coherent
            operational plan, a logframe for the project that was
            intended to make up for the absence of such a document at
            the time of project appraisal. The Bank also dealt firmly
            with deficiencies noted in financial management in December
            2002 by writing two successive letters to the Minister of
            Finance requesting corrective action. However, the Bank was
            slow to take action to correct monitoring and evaluation
            deficiencies, and to suggest the organizational and
            institutional reforms needed to spur project activities. The
            overall performance of the Borrower is rated unsatisfactory
            (U). Although there was consistent commitment to the project
            despite high turnover of government personnel and project
            staff, several recommendations from supervision missions
            were not implemented, and issues of monitoring and
            evaluation, financial management and institutional
            arrangements, although clearly identified, were not
            addressed effectively or in a timely manner. This project
            demonstrated the importance of beneficiary involvement in
            monitoring and evaluation. In particular, beneficiaries who
            contribute to project activities in cash or in kind should
            be involved in the planning and execution of those
            activities. Stakeholder participation and consensus-building
            are essential to a public-private partnership program.
            Stakeholders must be engaged early in the process, and then
            kept informed, in order to ensure sustainability and
            effective ownership. Other lessons pertained to the need to
            carefully select project implementation staff, who are
            business-oriented as well as technically competent; the need
            to have an independent body closely monitor the project,
            while striking a balance in this case, between Executing
            Agency control and autonomy; and the need for the Bank to
            react decisively to important recommendations from
            supervision missions, followed up by Government action.
            Lessons for the formulation of agribusiness projects were
            also detailed.
